sp.p: Heads-man dispatch, except Sempronio live, Lelio must die.

sp.speaker: Phil:
sp.p: Sempronio lives, my Lord, see where he stands.

sp.speaker: Du:
sp.p:
Hermit why dalliest thou?
Sempronio was young, but this is old,
Sempronio was dead, but he doth live:

sp.speaker: Her:
sp.p:
Old Sempronio now is young again,
And dead Sempronio now doth live,
Behold him Lelio, dost thou know him now?

sp.speaker: Lel:
sp.p: Sempronio.

sp.speaker: Sem:
sp.p: Ah dear Lelio.

sp.speaker: Her:
sp.p:
This Lord left dead by shepherds in the field,
Was found again, and healed thus by me,
And by my art having his hair disguised,
He past a solemn oath to hide his name,
And do good deeds where he had lived loose,
Since when, called Penitent Experience,
He hath remained, and lived a pensive life.
Speak my Sempronio, for I discharge thy vow,
Tell thou the rest, for why my vision
Foretold and promised such an accident,
As never Venice had, or saw the like.

sp.speaker: Sem:
sp.p:
Sempronio lives, and Lelio now must live,
Grieved for my breach of faith, grieved for my crime,
Here are the tokens of my fatal wounds,
Which when I eyed Annetta, I have wept,
To think upon my loose unbridled love.
Let us not joy in words, but joy in hearts,
And let our arms our tongues discourse embrace,
Where our three lives are heard of again,
Call them three knacks to find out honest men.

sp.speaker: Du:
sp.p:
God wrought these things, we do applaud his works
See how by mute embrace these friends embrace,
Mark how they whisper in each others ears,
Their troublous fortunes, cares, and discontents,
And now love works, see how Lelio hand in hand
Joins Sempronio with his Lucida,
The holy hermit knitteth up the knot,
And all applaud this unity of peace.
How now? what seeks this maid?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Pardon for my father.

sp.speaker: Du:
sp.p:
Comest thou to plead for Seruio Phillida?
Go fetch him forth, joy shall have fulness now:
Sempronio stand aside, we will make some sport.

body.stage: Enter Phillida with her father Seruio.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p:
Now Seruio, for thy forfeit to the state,
What fine wilt thou afford for liberty.

sp.speaker: Ser:
sp.p:
Dread Lord, those lands and profits fell to me.
By dear Sempronios death, my near a kin,
I frankly give in lieu of my contempt.

sp.speaker: Du:
sp.p:
What wilt thou make bequeath of others lands:
Why man he lives again.

sp.speaker: Ser:
sp.p: First tell me I am dead my Lord.

sp.speaker: Du:
sp.p: Thou must restore to him his goods again.

sp.speaker: Ser:
sp.p:
O misery, Is he restored to life, to take away my goods
Command me death, nay prisonment, and what ye will,
So he revive not, so I meet him not.

sp.speaker: Sem:
sp.p:
See here the picture of true avarice,
Where men prefer their goods before their friends,
How fare you uncle?

sp.speaker: Ser:
sp.p: Jesus bless me, a spirit. What cousin?

sp.speaker: Sem:
sp.p: Aye uncle, the same, and grieve not to yield your kinsman his right.

sp.speaker: Du:
sp.p:
Nay force perforce he shall restore thy own.
Phillida behold, thy uncle lives:
See my Lords, no care of kindred holdeth her,
She runs to meet Orphinio, love conducteth her.

sp.speaker: Phil:
sp.p: Are you returned my Lord, what safe returned?

sp.speaker: Orp:
sp.p: Returned to keep my faith with Phillida.

sp.speaker: Du:
sp.p:
Knit up that knot within with jollity,
And Register record this commodity.

sp.speaker: Sem:
sp.p:
Nay stay my Lord, before this comic end,
Let, measure knacks to find out honest men,
For all these listening ears would find them out.
Who list to know a perfect honest man,
Shall see his purse still open to the poor,
His tongue detesting lewd detractions,
He scorns to grieve the needful heart with grief,
But lives as born to every man's relief:
A knave will gain by all unlawful means,
But good men still their goods by virtue gleans.
A knave makes shift this thrift, forswears and lies,
An honest man on love and faith relies:
A knave makes lust his love, respects no friend,
An honest man for friendship life will spend.
O how I should tire both tongue, thought, and pen,
To scan out knaves from perfect honest men:
Point where I list, if so my finger light
On honesty, I swear I point aright.

sp.speaker: Du:
sp.p:
Thanks good Sempronio for this worthy skill,
To register the memory of this,
Henceforth wherever this history is heard,
The world shall praise thee, in whose life began,
The perfect knack to know an honest man.
